Or which of all the Devils dare

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: This Song
Was rarely formed to fit him.

sp.speaker: Orph.
sp.l: Charon o Charon
Thou wafter of the souls to bliss or bane

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Who calls the Ferry man of Hell?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Come near
And say who lives in joy, and whom in fear.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Those that die well; Eternal joy shall follow,
Those that die ill; their own soul fate shall swallow.

sp.speaker: Orph.
sp.l: Shall thy black Bark those guilty spirits slow
that kill themselves for love?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: O no no.
My cordage cracks when such great sins are near
No wind blows fair, nor I myself can steer

sp.speaker: Orph.
sp.l: What lovers pass and in Elizium reign?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Those gentle loves that are beloved again.

sp.speaker: Orph.
sp.l: This Soldier Loves, and fain would die to win.
Shall he go on?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: No it is too foul a sin
He must not come aboard: I dare not row,
Storms of despair and guilty blood will blow.

sp.speaker: Orph.
sp.l: Shall time release him say?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: No, no, no no.
Nor time nor death can alter us, nor prayer;
My boat is destiny and who then dare
But those appointed come aboard? Live still,
And love by reason mortal not by will.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: And when thy Mistress shall close up thine eyes

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Then come aboard and pass,

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Till when be wise

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Till when be wise.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: How still he sits: I hope this Song has settled him

sp.speaker: 1. Cap.
sp.l: He hires his lip, and rolls his fierce eyes yet
I fear for all this --

sp.speaker: 2. Cap.
sp.l: Stremon still apply to him;

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Give me more room then, sweetly strike divinely
Such strains and old earth moves at

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: The power I have over both Beast and plant
Thou man alone feelest miserable want
Strike your rare Spirits that attend my will,
And lose your savage wildness by my skill.
This Lion was a man of War that died,
As thou wouldst do to guild her Ladies pride
This Dog a fool that hung himself for love:
This Ape with daily hugging of a glove,
Forgot to eat and died. This goodly tree,
An usher that still grew before his Lady,
Withered at root. This, for he could not woo,
A grumbling Lawyer: This pied Bird a page,
that melted out because he wanted age.
Still these lie howling on the stygian shore,
O love no more, o love no more.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: He steals off silently, as though he would sleep,
No more but all be near him, feed his fancy
Good Stremon still; this may lock up his folly.
Yet Heaven knows I must fear him; away softly.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Did I not do most doggedly?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Most rarely?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: He is a brave man when shall we dog again;

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Untie me first for Gods sake,

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Help the Boy; he is in a wood poor child: good honey Stremon
Let us have a bear baiting; ye shall see me play
The rarest for a single Dog: at head all;
And if I do not win immortal glory,
Play, Dog play Devil.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Peace for this time,

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Prithee.
Let us sing him a black Santis, then let us all howl,
In our own beastly voices; tree keep your time,
Untie there; bow, wow, wow.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Away ye Ass, away,

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Why let us do something,
To satisfy the Gentleman, he is mad;
A Gentleman-like humour and in fashion,
And must have men as mad about him.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Peace
And come in quickly, it is ten to one else
He will find a staff to beat a dog; no more words,
I will get ye all employment; soft, soft, in all,

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: When camest thou over wench?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: But now this evening.
And have been ever since looking out Siphax,
In the wars he would have looked me: sure has gotten
Some other Mistress.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: A thousand wench, a thousand
They are as common here as Caterpillars
Among the corn, they eat up all the Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Are they so hungry? yet by their leave Chilax,
I will have a snatch too.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Dost thou love him still wench?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Why should I not? he had my Maiden head
And all my youth.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Thou art come the happiest
In the most blessed time, sweet wench the fittest,
If thou darest make thy fortune: by this light Cloe
And so I will kiss thee: and if thou wilt but let me,
For it is well worth a kindness.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: What should I let ye?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Enjoy thy minikin

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Thou art still old Chilax.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Still, still, and ever shall be: if, I say,
Thou wilt strike the stroke: I cannot do much harm wench

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Nor much good

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Siphax shall be thy Husband,
Thy very Husband woman, thy fool, thy Cuckold,
Or what thou wilt make him: I am overjoyed,
Ravished clean ravished with this fortune; kiss me,
Or I shall lose myself.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: My Husband said ye?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Said I? and will say Cloe: nay and do it
And do it home too; Peg thee as close to him
As birds are with a pin to one another;
I have it I can do it: thou wants clothes too,
And he will be hanged unless he marry thee
Ere he maintain thee: now he has Ladies, Courtiers
More than his back can bend at? multitudes
We are taken up for threshers, will ye bite?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Yes

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: And let me --

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Yes and let ye --

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: What!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Why that ye wot of,

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: The turn the good turn?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Any turn the Roach turn;

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: that is the right turn for that turns up the belly
I cannot stay take your instructions
And something toward household, come, whatever
I shall advise ye follow it exactly
And keep your times I point ye; for I will tell ye
A strange way you must wade through.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Fear not me Sir.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Come then and let us dispatch this modicum
For I have but an hour to stay, a short one
Besides more water for another mill
An old weak over shot I must provide for,
There is an old Nunnery at hand.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: A bawdy House.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: A pox consume it

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: If the stones (it is built on)
Were but as brickle as the flesh lives in it,
Your curse came handsomely: fear not, there is Ladies,
And other good sad people: your pinked Citizens
that think no shame to shake a sheet there: Come wench

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: A Soldier and so fearful?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Can ye blame me;
When such a wait lies on me?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Fie upon ye
I tell ye, ye shall have her: have her safely,
And for your wife with her own will,

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Good Sister --

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: What a distrustful man are you? tomorrow,
Tomorrow morning --

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Is it possible?
Can there be such a happiness?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Why hang me
If then ye be not married: if tomorrow night,
Ye do not --

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: O dear Sister --

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: What ye would do
What ye desire to do; lie with her: Devil,
What a dull man are you?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Nay I believe now,
And shall she love me?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: As her life and stroke ye,

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: O I will be her servant,

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: It is your duty,

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: And she shall have her whole will,

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Yes it is reason,
She is a Princes, and by that rule boundless

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: What would you be, for I would have ye Sister
Choose some great place about us: as her woman
Is not so fit.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: No, no, I shall find places:

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: And yet to be a Lady of her bedchamber,
I hold not so fit neither,
Some great title, believe it shall be looked out.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Ye may a Duchess
Or such a toy, a small thing pleases me Sir

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: What you will Sister: if a neighbour Prince,
When we shall come to reign --

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: We shall think on it,
Be ready at the time and in that place too,
And let me work the rest, within this half hour;
The Princess will be going, it is almost morning
Away and mind your business,

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Fortune bless us.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I do beseech your grace to banish me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why Gentleman is she not worthy marriage?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Most worthy, Sir, where worth again shall meet her,
But I like thick clouds sailing slow and heavy,
Although by her drawn higher; yet shall hide her
I dare not be a traitor; and it is treason,
But to imagine: as you love your honour --

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It is her first maiden doting and if crossed,
I know it kills her.

sp.speaker: 1 Lord.
sp.l: How knows your grace she loves him?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Her woman told me all; beside his story
Her maid Lucippe on what reason too,
And it is beyond all but enjoying.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Sir.
Even by your wisdom; by that great discretion
Ye owe to rule and order --

sp.speaker: 2 Lord.
sp.l: This man is mad sure,
To plead against his fortune --

sp.speaker: 1 Lord.
sp.l: And the King too,
Willing to have it so?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: By those dead Princes
From whose descents ye stand a star admired at,
Lay not so base a lay upon your vertues
Take heed for honours sake take heed: the bramble
No wise man ever planted by the rose,
It cankers all her beauty; nor the vine
When her full blushes courts the sun dares any
Choke up with wanton Ivy? good my Lords,
Who builds a monument, the Basis Jasper,
And the main body Brick?

sp.speaker: 2 Lord.
sp.l: Ye wrong your worth,
Ye are a Gentleman descended nobly.

sp.speaker: 1 Lord.
sp.l: In both bloods truly noble.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Say ye were not,
My will can make ye so.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: No, never, never;
It is not descent, nor will of Princes does it,
It is Virtue which I want it is Temperance,
Man, honest man is it fit your Majesty
Should call my drunkenness, my rashness brother?
Or such a blessed Maid my breach of faith,
For I am most lascivious; and fell angers
In which I am also mischievous, her husband?
O Gods preserve her! I am wild as Winter,
Ambitious as the Devil: out upon me,
I hate myself, sir, if ye dare bestow her
Upon a Subject ye have one deserves her.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But him she does not love: I know your meaning.
This young man's love unto his noble brother,
Appears a mirror; what must now be done Lords?
For I am gravelled, if she have not him
She dies for certain, if his brother miss her,
Farewell to him, and all our honours.

sp.speaker: 1 Lord.
sp.l: He is dead, sir,
Your Grace has heard of that , and strangely.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No,
I can assure ye no there was a trick in it,
Read that, and then know all; what ails the gentleman?
Hold him; how do ye sir?
Polidor is sick on the sudden.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Sick on the the sudden,
Extremely ill, wondrous ill.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Where did it take ye?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Here in my head sir, and my heart, for heaven sake.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Conduct him to his chamber presently,
And bid my Doctors --

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: No I shall be well sir,
I do beseech your Grace even for the Gods sake
Remember my poor brother, I shall pray then.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Away he grows more weaker still: I will do it,
Or heaven forget me ever. Now your Counsels,
For I am at my wits end; what with you sir?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: Letters from warlike Pelius.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yet more troubles?
The Spartans are in Arms, and like to win all:
Supplies are sent for and the General;
This is more cross than the other; come let us to him,
For he must have her, it is necessity,
Or we must lose our honours, let us plead all,
For more than all is needful, show all reason
If love can hear on that side, if she yield
We have fought best and won the noblest field.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.l: I have brought the wench, a lusty wench,
And somewhat like the Princess.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: It is the better, let us see her,
And go you in and tell him, that her Grace
Is come to visit him? how sleeps he Stremon?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: He cannot, only thinks, and calls on Polidor,
Swears he will not be fooled; sometimes he rages,
And sometimes sits and muses.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: He is past all help sure?
How do ye like her?

sp.speaker: 2 Capt.
sp.l: By the mass a good round Virgin,
And at first sight resembling, she is well clothed too.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: But is she sound?

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.l: Of wind and limb, I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: You are instructed Lady?

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.l: Yes, and know sir
How to behave myself, never fear.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: Polibius,
Where did he get this Vermin?

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.l: Hang him Badger,
There is not a hole free from him, whores and whores mates,
Do all pay him obedience.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: Indeed in the war,
His quarter was all whore, whore upon whore,
And lined with a whore, beshrew me it is a fair whore.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.l: She has smocked away her blood; but fair or foul,
Or blind or lame, that can but lift her leg up
Comes not amiss to him, he rides like a night mare,
All ages, all Religions.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: Can ye state it?

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.l: I will make a shift.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: He must lie with ye, Lady.

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.l: Let him, he is not the first man I have lain with,
Nor shall not be the last.

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.l: He comes, no more words,
She has her lesson thoroughly; how he views her?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Go forward now, so, bravely, stand!

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Great Lady,
How humbly I am bound --

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.l: You shall not kneel sir,
Come, I have done you wrong; stand up my Soldier,
And thus I make amends --

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: A plague confound ye,
Is this your state?

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.l: It is well enough.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: O Lady,
Your royal hand, your hand my dearest beauty
Is more than I must purchase: here divine one,
I dare revenge my wrongs: ha?

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.l: A damned foul one.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: The Lees of bawdy prunes: mourning gloves?
All spoiled by heaven.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ha! who art thou?

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.l: A shame on ye,
Ye clawing scabby whore.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I say, who art thou?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Why it is the Princess sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: The devil sir,
It is some rogue thing.

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.l: If this abuse be love sir,
Or I that laid aside my modesty --

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: So far thou wilt never find it.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Do not weep,
For if ye be the Princess, I will love ye,
Indeed I will, and honour ye, fight for ye,
Come wipe your eyes; by heaven she stinks; who art thou?
Stinks like a poisoned Rat behind a hanging?
Woman, who art thou? like a rotten Cabbage.

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.l: Ye are much to blame sir, it is the Princess.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: How?
She the Princess?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: And the loving Princess.

sp.speaker: 1 Capt.
sp.l: Indeed the doting Princess.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Come hither once more,
The Princess smells like mornings breath, pure Amber,
Beyond the courted Indies in her spices
Still a dead rat by heaven; thou art a Princess.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: What a dull whore is this?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I will tell ye presently,
For if she be a Princess, as she may be
And yet stink too, and strongly, I shall find her;
Fetch the Numidian Lion I brought over,
If she be sprung from royal blood, the Lion
He will do ye reverence, else

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.l: I beseech your Lordship?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: He will tear her all to pieces.

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.l: I am no Princess, sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Who brought thee hither?

sp.speaker: 2. Capt.
sp.l: If ye confess, we will hang ye.

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.l: Good my Lord;

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Who art thou then?

sp.speaker: Who.
sp.l: A poor retaining whore, sir,
To one of your Lordships Captains.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Alas poor whore,
Go, be a whore still, and stink worse: Ha, ha ha
What fools are these, and coxcombs?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: I am right glad yet,
He takes it with such lightness.

sp.speaker: 1. Cap.
sp.l: Methinks his face too
Is not so clouded as it was; how he looks?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Where is your dead Rat?

sp.speaker: 2. Cap.
sp.l: The devil dine upon her
Lions, why what a medicine had he gotten
To try a whore?

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: Here is one from Polidor stays to speak with ye.

sp.speaker: Eume.
sp.l: With whom?

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: With all; where has the General been?
He is laughing to himself extremely.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Come,
I will tell thee how: I am glad yet he is so merry.

div2.stage: Enter Chilax and Priest, Calis, Lady and Nun.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: What lights are those that enter there, still nearer?
Plague on your rotten itch, do you draw me hither
Into the Temple to betray me? was there no place
To satisfy your sin in ? Gods forgive me,
Still they come forward;

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.l: Peace ye fool, I have found it,
It is the young Princess Calis.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: It is the devil
To claw us for our caterwauling.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Retire softly,
I did not look for you these two hours, Lady,
Beshrew your haste: that way,

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: that goes to the Altar?
Ye old blind Beast.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I know not any way;
Still they come nearer,
I will in to the Oracle;

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: that is well remembered I will in with ye;

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Do.

div2.stage:
Enter Calis and her Traine with lights singing;
Lucippe, Cleanthe

sp.l: O fair sweet Goddess Queen of Loves,
Soft and gentle, as thy Doves,
Humble eyed, and ever ruing
Those poor hearts, their Loves pursuing:
O thou mother of delights,
Crowner of all happy nights,
Star of dear content, and pleasure
Of mutual loves the endless treasure,
Accept this sacrifice we bring
Thou continual youth and Spring,
Grant this Lady her desires,
And every hour, we will crown thy sires.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.l: You about her all retire,
Whilst the Princess feeds the fire,
When your Devotions ended be
To the Oracle I will attend ye.

div2.stage:
Exit. Nun & draws
the Curten close to Calis.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: He will abroad.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: How does his humour hold him?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: He is now grown wondrous sad, weeps often too,
Talks of his brother to himself, starts strangely.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Does he not curse?

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Nor break out in fury,
Offering some new attempt?

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: Neither, to the Temple
Is all we hear of now: what there he will do;

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: I hope repent his folly, let us be near him.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Where are the rest?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: About a business
Concerns him mainly, if heaven cure this madness,
He is man forever Stremon.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Does the King know it?

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Yes, and much troubled with it, is now gone
To seek his sister out.
Come let us away then.

div2.stage: Enter Nun, she opens the Curtain to Calis.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.l: Peace to your prayers Lady, will it please ye
To pass on to the Oracle.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: Most humbly.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Do ye hear that ?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Yes, lie close.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: A wildfire take ye,
What shall become of me? I shall be hanged now.
Is this a time to shake? a halter shake ye,
Come up and juggle, come.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I am monstrous fearful.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Up ye old gaping Oyster, up and answer,
A mouldy mange upon your chops, ye told me
I was safe here till the Bell rung.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I was prevented,
And did not look these three hours for the Princess.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Shall we be taken?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Speak for loves sake Chilax?
I cannot, nor I dare not.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I will speak treason, for I had as lief be hanged for that

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Good Chilax.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Must it be sung or said? what shall I tell them?
They are here? here now preparing.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: O, my conscience!

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Plague on your spur-galled conscience, does it tire now?
Now when it should be toughest? I could make thee --

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Save us, we are both undone else.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Down ye dog then,
Be quiet, and be stanch to no inundations.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.l: Here kneel again, and Venus grant your wishes.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: O Divine star of Heaven,
Thou in power above the seven:
Thou sweet kindler of desires,
Till they grow to mutual fires:
Thou, O gentle Queen that art,
Curer of each wounded heart.
Thou the fuel, and the flame;
Thou in heaven, and here the same:
Thou the wooer, and the wood:
Thou the hunger, and the food:
Thou the prayer, and the prayed;
Thou what is, or shall be said:
Thou still young, and golden tressed,
Make me by thy Answer blessed.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: When?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Now speak handsomely, and small by all means,
I have told ye what.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: But I will tell you a new tale
Now for my neck verse; I have heard thy prayers,
And mark me well.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.l: The Goddess is displeased much,
The Temple shakes and totters: she appears,
Bow, Lady, bow.

sp.speaker: Venus.
sp.l: Purge me the Temple round,
And live by this example henceforth sound
Virgin, I have seen thy tears,
Heard thy wishes and thy fears,
Thy holy Incense flew above,
Hark therefore, thy doom in love,
Had thy heart been soft at first,
Now thou hadst allayed thy thirst:
Had thy stubborn will but bended,
All thy sorrows here had ended;
Therefore be just in love,
And strange fortune thou must prove,
And, for thou hast been stern and coy,
A dead love thou shalt enjoy.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: O gentle goddess!

sp.speaker: Venus.
sp.l: Rise, thy doom is said,
And fear not; I shall please thee with the dead,

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.l: Go up into the Temple and there end
Your holy rites, the Goddess smiles upon ye.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I will no more Oracles, nor Miracles,
Nor no more Church work, I will be drawn and hanged first:
Am not I torn in pieces with the thunder?
Death, I can scarce believe I live yet,
It gave me on the buttocks, a cruel, a huge bang,
I had as lieve had them scratched with dog-whips;
Be quiet henceforth, now ye feele the end of it,
I would advise ye my old friends the good gentlewoman
Is strucken dumb, and there her grace sits mumping
Like an old Ape eating a Brawn; sure the good Goddess
Knew my intent was honest, to save the Princess.
And how we young men are enticed to wickedness
By these lewd women, I had paid for it else too:
I am monstrous holy now, and cruel fearful,
O! it was a plaguey thump, charged with a vengeance.
sp.stage:
Enter Siphax, walkes softly over the Stage,
and goes in.
sp.l: Would I were well at home; the best is it is not day:
Who that ? ha? Siphax? I will be with you anon, sir,
Ye shall be Oracled I warrant ye,
And thundered too as well as I: your Lordship
sp.stage:
Enter Memnon, Eumenes, Stremon, and
two carrying Torches.
sp.l: Must needs enjoy the Princess, yes, ha! torches?
And Memnon coming this way, he is dog mad,
And ten to one appearing thus unto him,
He worries me, I must go by him.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ask me no further questions; what art thou?
How dost thou stare? stand off; nay look upon me,
I do not shake, nor fear thee. --

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: He will kill me,
This is for Church work.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Why dost thou appear now?
Thou wert fairly slain: I know thee Diocles,
And know thine envy to mine honour: but --

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Stay Memnon,
I am a Spirit, and thou canst not hurt me.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: This is the voice of Chilax.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: What makes he thus?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: It is true that I was slain in field, but foully
By multitudes not manhood: therefore mark me,
I do appear again to quit mine honour,
And on thee single.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I accept the challenge.
Where?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: On the Stygian banks

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: When?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Four days hence.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Go noble Ghost, I will attend.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I thank ye.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Ye have saved your throat, and handsomely:
Farewell sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Sing me the Battle of Pelusium,
In which this Worthy died.

sp.speaker: Eumen.
sp.l: This will spoil all, and make him worse
Than ever he was, sit down sir,
And give yourself to rest.
Arm, arm, arm, arm, the Scouts are all come in
Keep your ranks close and now your honours win.
Behold from yonder hill, the foe appears,
Bows, bills glaves arrows shields, and Spears,
Like a dark wood he comes, or tempest pouring.
O view the wings of horse, the meadows scouring,
The van-guard marches bravely, hark the Drums -- dub, dub,
They meet they meet, now the Battle comes,
See how the Arrows fly
that darken all the sky,
Hark how the Trumpets sound,
Hark how the hills rebound, -- Tara-tara-tara.
Hark how the horses charge: in boys, in boys, in , -- tara, tara,
The Battle totters; now the wounds begin,
O how they cry,
O how they die.
Room for the valiant Memnon, armed with thunder,
See how he breaks the ranks asunder:
They fly, they fly, Eumenes has the Chase,
And brave Posibius, makes good his place.
To the plains, to the Woods,
To the Rocks to the floods,
They fly for succour: Follow, follow, follow, Hey, hey.
Hark how the Soldiers hollow
Brave Diocles is dead,
And all his Soldiers fled,
Though battell is won, and lost,
that many a life hath cost.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Now forward to the Temple.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Are ye gone?
How have I scaped this morning? by what miracle?
Sure I am ordained for some brave end.

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: How is it?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Come, it is as well as can be.

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: But is it possible
This should be true you tell me?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: It is most certain.

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: Such a gross Ass to love the Princess?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Peace,
Pull your robe close about ye: you are perfect
In all I taught ye.

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: Sure.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Gods give thee good luck,
It is strange my brains should still be beating knavery
For all these dangers: but they are needful mischiefs,
And such are Nuts to me, and I must do them,
You will remember me --

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: By this kiss Chilax.

sp.speaker: Chilax.
sp.l: No more of that , I fear another Thunder.

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: We are not in the Temple man.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Peace, here he comes,
Now to our business handsomely: away now.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: It was sure the Princess, for he kneeled unto her,
And she looked every way: I hope the Oracle
Has made me happy: me I hope she looked for.
sp.stage: Enter Chilax and Cloe at the other doore.
sp.l: Fortune, I will so honour thee, Love so adore thee,
She is here again looks round about again too,
It is done, I know it is done; it is Chilax with her,
And I shall know of him; who is that ?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Speak softly,
The Princess from the Oracle.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: She views me,
By heaven she beckons me.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Come near, she would have ye.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: O royal Lady.
Kisses her hand.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: She wills ye read that , for belike she is bound to silence.
For such a time; she is wondrous gracious to ye.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Heaven make me thankful.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: She would have ye read it,

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Siphax, the will of Heaven hath cast me on thee
To be thy wife, whose will must be obeyed:
Use me with honour, I shall love thee dearly,
And make thee understand thy worths hereafter;
Convey me to a secret Ceremony,
that both our hearts and loves may be united,
And use no language, till before my brother.
We both appear, where I will show the Oracle,
For till that time I am bound, I must not answer.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: O happy I!

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Ye are a made man.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: But Chilax
Where are her women?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: None but your Graces Sister,
Because she would have it private to the world yet,
Knows of this business.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: I shall thank the Chilax,
Thou art a careful man.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Your Graces servant.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: I will find a fit place for thee.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: If you will not,
There is a good Lady will she points ye forward,
Away and take your fortune, not a word sir,
So, you are greased I hope.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Stremon, Fool, Picus.
Where have you left your Lord?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: in the Temple, Chilax.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Why are ye from him?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Why the King is with him,
And all the Lords.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Is not the Princess there too.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Yes,
And the strangest coil amongst them: She weeps bitterly;
The King entreats, and frowns, my Lord like Autumn
Drops off his hopes by handfuls, all the Temple
Sweats with this Agony.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Where is young Polidor?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Dead as they said on the sudden.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Dead?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: For certain,
But not yet known abroad.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: There is a new trouble;
A brave young man he was; but we must all die.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Did not the General meet you this morning
Like a tall stallion Nun?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: No more of that Boy.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: You had been ferreting.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: that is all one, Fool;
My Master fool that taught my wits to traffic,
What has your wisdom done? how have you profited?
Out with your Audit, come: you are not empty,
Put out mine eye with twelve pence? do you shaker?
What think you of this shaking? here is wit coxcomb
Ha boys? ha my fine rascals, here is a Ring,
Pulls out a Purse.
How right they go?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: O let me ring the fore-bell.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: And here are thumpers, Chickens, golden rogues,
Fit wit ye rascals.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: I have a Sty here Chilax.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I have no gold to cure it, not a penny,
Not one cross Cavalier; we are dull Soldiers,
Gross, heavy-headed fellows; fight for victuals?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Why; ye are the spirits of the time.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: By no means.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: The valiant fiery.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Fie, fie no.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Believe me sir.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I would I could sir.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: I will satisfy ye.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: But I will not content you; alas poor boy,
Thou showest an honest nature weeps for thy Master,
There is a red rogue to buy thee handkerchers.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: He was an honest Gentleman, I have lost too.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Ye have indeed your labour Fool; but Stremon,
Dost thou want money too? no virtue living?
No firking out at fingers ends?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: It seems so.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Will ye all serve me?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: Yes, when ye are Lord General,
For less I will not go.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: There is gold for thee then,
Thou hast a soldiers mind, Fool.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: Here, your first man.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I will give thee for thy wit, for it is a fine wit,
A dainty diving wit, hold up; just nothing,
Go graze in the commons, yet I am merciful
There is six pence; buy a Saucer, steal an old gown,
And beg in the Temple for a Prophet, come away boys,
Let us see how things are carried, Fool, up sirrah,
You may chance get a dinner: Boy your preferment
I will undertake, for your brave Masters sake,
You shall not perish.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: Chilax.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Please me well Fool,
And you shall light my pipes: Away to the Temple.
But stay, the Kings here, sport upon sport Boys.

div2.stage: Enter King, Lords, Siphax kneeling, Cloe with a Vaile.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What would you have Captain,
Speak suddenly, for I am wondrous busy.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: A Pardon, Royal sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: For that ,
Which was heavens will, should not be mine alone sir;
My marrying with this Lady.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It needs no Pardon,
For marriage is no sin.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.l: Not in itself, sir,
But in presuming too much: Yet heaven knows
So does the Oracle that cast it on me,
And -- the Princess, royal sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What Princess?

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: O be not angry, my dread King, your Sister.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My sister? she is in the Temple man.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: She is here sir.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: The Captain is mad, she is kneeling at the Altar.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I know she is, with all my heart good Captain.
I do forgive ye both: be unvailed Lady;
Puts off her vail
Will ye have more forgiveness? the man is frantic,
Come let us go bring her out: God give ye joy, sir.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: How? Cloe? my old Cloe?

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: Even the same sir.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Gods give your manhood much content.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: The Princess
Looks something musty since her coming over.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.l: It were good, you would brush her over.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: Fools and Fiddlers
Make sport at my abuse too.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: O it is the nature
Of us Fools to make bold with one another,
But you are wise, brave sirs.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Cheer up your Princess,
Believe it sir, the King will not be angry,
Or say he were; why it was the Oracle,
The Oracle, if like your Grace, the Oracle.

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: And who, most mighty Siphax?

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: With mine own whore.

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: With whom else should ye marry speak your conscience,
Will ye transgress the law of Arms, that ever
Rewards the Soldier with his own sins?

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: Devils.

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: Ye had my maiden-head, my youth, my sweetness,
Is it not justice then? --

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: I see it must be,
But by this hand. I will hang a lock upon thee.

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: You shall not need, my honesty shall do it.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: If there be wars in all the world --

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: I will with ye,
For you know, I have been a soldier,
Come, curse on: when I need another Oracle.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Send for me Siphax, I will fit ye with a Princess,
And so to both your honours.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: And your graces.

sp.speaker: Siph.
sp.l: The Devil grace ye all.

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.l: God-a-mercy Chilax,

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Shall we laugh half an hour now?

sp.speaker: Strem.
sp.l: No the King comes,
And all the train.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Away then, our Act is ended.

div2.stage:
Enter King, Calis. Memnon and Cleanthe,
Curtisan, Lords.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You know he does deserve ye, loves ye dearly,
You know what bloody violence had used
sp.stage: The Hearse ready Polidor, Eumenes & Captains
sp.l: Upon himself, but that his brother crossed it,
You know the same thoughts still inhabit in him
And covet to take birth: Look on him Lady,
The wars have not so far consumed him yet,
Cold age disabled him, or sickness sunk him
To be abhorred; look on his Honour sister,
that bears no stamp of time, no wrinkles on it,
No sad demolishment, nor death can reach it:
Look with the eyes of heaven that nightly waken,
To view the wonders of my glorious Maker,
And not the weakness: look with your virtuous eyes,
And then clad royalty in all his conquests;
His matchless love hung with a thousand merits
Eternal youth attending, Fame and Fortune,
Time and Oblivion vexing at his vertues,
He shall appear a miracle: look on our dangers,
Look on the public ruin.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: O, dear brother.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Fie, let us not like proud and greedy waters
Gain, to give off again: this is our Sea,
And you his Cynthia, govern him, take heed,
His floods have been as hie, and full as any,
And gloriously now is got up to the girdle,
The Kingdoms he hath purchased; noble Sister,
Take not your virtue from him, O take heed
We ebb not now to nothing, take heed Calis.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: The will of heaven not mine, which must not alter,
And my eternal doom for aught I know
Is fixed upon me; alas, I must love nothing,
Nothing that loves again must I be blessed with:
The gentle Vine climbs up the Oak and clips him
And when the stroke comes, yet they fall together;
Death, death must I enjoy, and live to love him,
O noble Sir!

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Those tears are some reward yet,
Pray let me wed your sorrows.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: Take them Soldier,
They are fruitful ones, lay but a sight upon them,
And strait they will conceive to infinities;
I told ye what, ye could find them,
Room before there.

div2.stage: Enter Funerall, Captaines following, and Eumenes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How now, what is this? more drops to the ocean?
Whose body is this?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: The noble Polidor,
This speaks his death.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: My Brother dead?

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: O Goddess!
O cruel, cruel Venus, here is my fortune.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Read Captain.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Read aloud: farewell my follies.

sp.speaker: 1. Cap.
sp.l: To the Excellent Princess Calis.
Be wise, as you are beauteous, love with judgment,
And look with clear eyes on my noble Brother,
Value desert and virtue, they are Jewels,
Fit for your worth and wearing: take heed Lady,
The Gods reward ingratitude most grievous;
Remember me no more, or if you must,
Seek me in noble Memnons love, I dwell there:
I durst not live, because I durst not wrong him,
I can no more, make me eternal happy
With looking down upon your loves.
Farewell.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: And didst thou die for me?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Excellent virtue!
What will ye now do?

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: Dwell forever here sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: For me dear Polidor? o worthy young man!
O love, love, love, love above recompense!
Infinite love, infinite honesty!
Good Lady leave, you must have no share here,
Take home your sorrows: here is enough to store me,
Brave glorious griefs! was ever such a brother?
Turn all the stories over in the world yet,
And search through all the memories of mankind,
And find me such a friend; he has out-done all,
Outstripped them sheerly, all, all, thou hast Polidor,
To die for me; why, as I hope for happiness,
It was one of the rarest thought on things
The bravest, and carried beyond compass of our actions,
I wonder how he hit it, a young man too,
In all the blossoms of his youth and beauty,
In all the fullness of his veins and wishes
Wooed by that Paradise, that would catch heaven;
It starts me extremely, thou blessed Ashes,
Thou faithful monument, where love and friendship
Shall while the world is, work new miracles.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: O! let me speak too.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: No not yet, thou man,
For we are but man's shadows, only man,
I have not words to utter him; speak Lady,
I will think a while.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: The Goddess grants me this yet,
I shall enjoy the dead: no tomb shall hold thee
But these two arms, no Trickments but my tears
Over thy Hearse, my sorrows like sad arms
Shall hang for ever: on the toughest Marble
Mine eyes shall weep thee out an Epitaph,
Love at thy feet shall kneel, his smart bow broken;
Faith at thy head, youth and the Graces mourners;
O sweet young man!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now I begin to melt too.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Have ye enough yet Lady? room for a gamester
To my fond Love, and all those idle fancies
A long farewell, thou diedest for me dear Polidor,
To give me peace, thou hast eternal glory,
I stay and talk here; I will kiss thee first,
And now I will follow thee.

sp.speaker: Pollidor.
sp.l: Hold, for heavens sake!

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ha!
Does he live?
Dost thou deceive me?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Thus far,
Yet for your good, and honour.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now dear sister;

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: The Oracle is ended, noble sir,
Dispose me now as you please.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: You are mine then?

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: With all the joys that may be.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Your consent sir;

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ye have it freely.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Walk along with me then,
And as you love me, love my will.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: I will so.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Here worthy Brother, take this virtuous Princess,
Ye have deserved her nobly, she will love ye,
And when my life shall bring ye peace, as she does,
Command it, ye shall have it.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Sir, I thank ye.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I never found such goodness in such years.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Thou shalt not over-do me, though I die for it,
O how I love thy goodness, my best brother,
You have given me here a treasure to enrich me,
Would make the worthiest King alive a beggar,
What may I give you back again?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Your love sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: And you shall have it, even my dearest love,
My first, my noblest love, take her again, sir,
She is yours, your honesty has over-run me,
She loves ye, lovest her not? excellent Princess,
Enjoy thy wish, and now get Generals.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: As ye love heaven, love him, she is only yours, sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: As ye love heaven, love him, she is only yours, sir;
My Lord, the King.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: He will undo himself sir,
And must without her perish; who shall fight then?
Who shall protect your Kingdom?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Give me hearing,
And after that belief, were she my soul
(As I do love her equal) all my victories,
And all the living names I have gained by war,
And living him that good, that virtuous good man,
that only worthy of the name of brother,
I would resign all freely, it is all love
To me, all marriage rites, the joy of issues
To know him fruitful, that has been so faithful.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: This is the noblest difference -- take your choice sister.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: I see they are so brave, and noble both,
I know not which to look on.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Choose discreetly,
And virtue guide ye, there all the world in one man
Stands at the mark.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: There all man's honesty,
The sweetness of all youth --

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: O Gods!

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: My Armour,
By all the Gods she is yours; my arms, I say,
And I beseech your Grace, give me employment,
that shall be now my Mistress: here my Courtship.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ye shall have anything.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Virtuous Lady,
Remember me, your servant now; Young man,
You cannot over-reach me in your goodness;
O love! how sweet thou lookest now? and how gentle,
I should have slubbered thee, and stained thy beauty;
Your hand, your hand sir;

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Take her, and Heaven bless her.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: It is your will sir, nothing of my merit;
And as your royal gift, I take this blessing.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: And I from heaven this gentleman: thanks Goddess.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: So ye are pleased now Lady;

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Now or never.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: My cold stiff carcass, would have frozen ye,
Wars, wars.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ye shall have wars.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: My next brave battle
I dedicate to your bright honour (sister,)
Give me a favour, that the world may know
I am your soldier.

sp.speaker: Calis.
sp.l: This, and all fair Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: And he that bears this from me, must strike boldly.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I do forgive thee: be honest, no more wench.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come now to Revels, this blessed day shall prove
The happy crown of noble Faith and Love.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: To please all is impossible, and to despair
Ruins ourselves, and damps the Writers care:
Would we knew what to do, or say, or when
To find the minds here equal with the men:
But we must venture; now to Sea we go,
Fair fortune with us, give us room, and blow;
Remember ye are all venturers; and in this Play
How many twelve-pences ye have stowed this day:
Remember for return of your delight,
We launch, and plough through storms of fear, and spite:
Give us your fore-winds fairly, fill our wings,
And steer us right, and as the Sailors sing,
Laden with Wealth, on wanton seas, so we
Shall make our home-bound-voyage cheerfully;
And you our noble Merchants, for your treasure
Share equally the fraught, we run for pleasure.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: Here lies the doubt now, let our Plays be good,
Our own care sailing equal in this Flood;
Our preparations new, new our Attire,
Yet here we are becalmed still, still in the mire,
Here we stick fast; Is there no way to clear
This passage of your judgment, and our fear,
No mitigation of that law? Brave friends,
Consider we are yours, made for your ends,
And everything preserves itself, each will
If not perverse, and crooked, utters still
The best of that it ventures in : have care
Even for your pleasures sake, of what we are,
And do not ruin all: You may frown still.
But it is the nobler way, to check the will.
